occurrences.line_text: Declare it boldly Dame, and doe not stand in dout.
That shall I sooth (said he) to you declare.
And for what cause declare, so mote ye not repent?
But plainely gan to him declare the case
The which as commeth now, by course I will declare.
In this exploite, me needeth to declare,
His wondrous worth declared in all mens view.
All which was thus to him declared by that Squire.
My brother here declared hath to you:
Would needes depart, as shall declared be elsewhere.
Through the greene gras his long bright burnisht backe declares.
Right firme & strong, though somewhat they declind;
And now faire Phoebus gan decline in hast
Decline her head, & touch her crouper with her crowne.
And into her faire bosome made his grapes decline.
Liftes vp his head, that did before decline
And meeting Plim, to Plimmouth thence declines:
He is declyned from that marke of theirs,
Amongst them all this end he did decree;
Not so; for what the Fates do once decree,
Vnweeting of the Fates diuine decree,
Till fortune did perforce it so decree.
But if that life ye vnto me decree,
The eare must be the ballance, to decree
How worthily, by heauens high decree,
Mongst whom his realme he equally decreed
For th'heauens haue decreed, to displace
And thought t'appeale from that, which was decreed,
And if to that auenge by you decreed
Vnto the Castle where they had decreed.
for loues disdaine decreed.
Yet mote he not withstand, what was decreede;
And all decrepit in his feeble corse,
Of lawes, of iudgements, and of decretals;
His strength still more, but she still more decrewed.
Still drownd in sleepe, and most of his dayes ded;
As ashes pale of hew and seeming ded;
These eyes did see that knight both liuing and eke ded.
The mossy braunches of an Oke halfe ded.
Did paint his chearefull cheekes, yet being ded,
Hable to heale the sicke, and to reuiue the ded.
The loathed leachour. But the Dame halfe ded
The hart out of his brest: for sith her ded
To turne his steede about, or sure he should be ded.
Transfixed with the speare, downe tombled ded
But soone he shall be found, and shortly doen be ded.
The old man could not fly, but fell to ground halfe ded.
As that I did mistake the liuing for the ded.
He slaughtred had, and ere they were halfe ded,
That many there were missing, which were ded,
That dedicated is t'Olympicke Ioue,
From whence the riuer Dee as siluer cleene
And passing Dee with hardy enterprise,
And following Dee, which Britons long ygone
Being in deed old Archimage, did stay
Is not his deed, what euer thing is donne,
Dead was it sure, as sure as death in deed,
To thinke without desert of gentle deed,
That I may wreake on them their hainous hatefull deed.
In braue pursuit of honorable deed,
Drad for his derring do, and bloudy deed;
That am the author of this hainous deed,
Nath'lesse most heauenly faire in deed and vew
For knighthoods loue, do not so foule a deed,
After so wicked deed why liu'st thou lenger day?
For these same Monsters are not these in deed,
That either seemes some cursed witches deed,
And win him worship through his warlike deed,
To her no euill thought, nor euill deed;
Thy life she saued by her gracious deed,
In deed Sir knight (said he) one word may tell
Where most sweet hymmes of this thy famous deed
Malbecco seeing them resolu'd in deed
With loosenesse of her loue, and loathly deed,
What booteth then the good and righteous deed,
Yield you in liew of this your gratious deed?
But that young Knight, which through her gentle deed
Ne more sincere in word and deed profest;
And yeeld great thankes for their so goodly deed,
And forced me to so infamous deed,
But Artegall seeing his cruell deed,
By late ensample of that courteous deed,
They should accomplish both a knightly deed,
The which hath doen to thee this wrongfull deed,
The wretch, that hyr'd you to this wicked deed.
He weened well, that he in deed was dead,
For such a dismall deed, their guilt to hyde:
Hath wrought this wicked deed: doe feare away, and tell.
Right faithfull true he was in deede and word,
Though nor in word nor deede ill meriting,
For neuer knight, that dared warlike deede,
In word and deede that shew'd great modestie,
For when the cause of that outrageous deede
But inly thought of that despightfull deede
That seem'd he was full bent to some mischieuous deede.
To be auenged for so fowle a deede,
Nor land nor fee, for hyre of his good deede,
And of her selfe in very deede so deemed;
To haue done much more admirable deedes.
Inquireth of our states, and of our knightly deedes.
And all the day in doing good and godly deedes.
Yet not so good of deedes, as great of name,
Of whose fowle deedes, too hideous to be told
Through deedes of armes and prowesse martiall;
Of his owne vertues, and prayse-worthy deedes.
Whose noble deedes aboue the Northerne starre
With noble deedes, and warreyd on Brunchild
With mightie deedes their sundry gouernments;
All my delight on deedes of armes is set,
His cruell deedes and wicked wyles did spot:
Of his mischieuous deedes, and said, that hee
Far from all neighbours, that her deuilish deedes
And deedes of armes aboue all Dames is deemed,
That deedes of armes had euer in despaire,
That they thy vertuous deedes may imitate,
To proue some deedes of armes vpon an equall pere.
Her deedes were forged, and her words false coynd,
Their fight and warlike deedes.
The seedes of euill wordes, and factious deedes;
She modest was in all her deedes and words,
To view and deeme the deedes of armes that day;
For euill deedes may better then bad words be bore.
Assembled were their deedes of armes to shew.
Full many deedes that day were shewed plaine:
Braue thoughts and noble deedes did euermore aspire.
Which did in noble deedes of armes excell,
Their greatest glory, for their rightfull deedes,
Expert in battell and in deedes of armes;
Her name is Munera, agreeing with her deedes.
To deedes of armes and proofe of cheualrie
Full many deedes of armes that day were donne,
Through hard aduentures deedes of armes to try,
Saying; Deare Lady, deedes ought not be scand
To loose the badge, that should his deedes display.
Of the lewd words and deedes, which he had done:
As their victorious deedes haue often showen,
And did right noble deedes, the which elswhere are showne.
In doing gentle deedes with franke delight,
And sing of Knights and Ladies gentle deeds;
He hated all good workes and vertuous deeds,
And when her curteous deeds he did compare,
But deeds of armes must I at last be faine,
Braue be her warres, and honorable deeds,
Whose glory is in gracious deeds, and ioyes
And mightie deeds, should matched haue the best:
From seeking praise, and deeds of armes abrode,
For loue does alwayes bring forth bounteous deeds,
Does all their deeds deface, and dims their glories all.
Whence spring all noble deeds and neuer dying fame:
That all her goodly deeds do well declare.
Her noble deeds, ne her right course for ought forsooke.
Of his bad deeds, which dayly he increast,
Of deeds of armes, which vnto them became,
In sewing deeds of armes, my liues and labours end.
Was then assembled, deeds of armes to see:
And gan to treate of deeds of armes abrode,
With which she wondrous deeds of arms atchieued,
There Marinell great deeds of armes did shew;
That all obedience both to words and deeds
The gentle minde by gentle deeds is knowne.
By such discourteous deeds discouering his base kind.
Amongst that rusticke rout in all his deeds,
Yt nought too deare I deemd, while so my dear I sought.
Her many deemd to haue beene of the Fayes,
A goodly creature, whom he deemd in mind
Her entertaynd; nath'lesse she inly deemd
And thereby deemd the beast had bene depriu'd
And eke that Idoll deem'd so costly dere;
She deem'd him sure to haue bene dead on ground,
That sure he deem'd him borne of noble race.
I deeme your loue, and hold me to you bound;
In doubt to deeme her borne of earthly brood;
Who thereby dead that balefull Beast did deeme,
Elissa (so the eldest hight) did deeme
And that my falser friend did no lesse ioyous deeme.
Varlet, this place most dew to me I deeme,
Ne deeme thy force by fortunes doome vniust,
And deeme them roote of all disquietnesse;
Ne canst of prowesse, ne of knighthood deeme,
Bad therefore I him deeme, that thus lies dead on field.
Mote deeme him borne with ill disposed skyes,
Would surely deeme it to be yuie trew:
Well did Antiquitie a God thee deeme,
Daughter, I deeme that counsell aye most fit,
Farre better I it deeme to die with speed,
Deeme of her high desert, or seeme so light:
And doubted her to deeme an earthly wight,
Extremely mad the man I surely deeme,
I loath as doung, ne deeme my dew reward:
The Seneschall was cal'd to deeme the right,
In doubt to whom she victorie should deeme,
To view and deeme the deedes of armes that day;
To deeme this doutfull case, for which they all co[n]tended.
That when your pleasure is to deeme aright,
Hard is the doubt, and difficult to deeme,
Yet glasse was not, if one did rightly deeme,
And if ye deeme me death for louing one,
The whiles I him condemne, and deeme his paine,
And deeme vnworthy or of loue or life,
Not so thou Squire, (he sayd) but thine I deeme
Of things vnseene how canst thou deeme aright,
For vaine it is to deeme of things aright,
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
Some men, I wote, will deeme in Artegall
And deeme it doen of will, that through inforcement came.
Him they did deeme, as sure to them he seemed,
My due reward, the which right well I deeme
Saint George himself ye would haue deemed him to be.
End of the doubtfull battell deemed tho
And deedes of armes aboue all Dames is deemed,
Proud man himselfe then Braggadocchio deemed,
Made her not yeeld so much, as due she deemed.
Nathlesse proud man himselfe the other deemed,
With diuerse fortune doubtfull to be deemed:
For last is deemed best. To her therefore
That which of them was best, mote not be deemed.
So was she guiltie deemed of them all.
As that he in his mind her worthy deemed,
And of her selfe in very deede so deemed;
So her he deemes already but a damned ghoste.
Him deeming dead, as then he seemd in sight,
Who thereby deeming sure the thing as donne,
Deeming them doughtie as they did appeare,
In all the skill of deeming wrong and right,
And sayd, Fond dame that deem'st of things diuine
Is cal'de Blacke water, and the Liffar deep,
Wherein old dints of deepe wounds did remaine,
And forth he cald out of deepe darknesse dred
And through the world of waters wide and deepe,
And vnto Morpheus comes, whom drowned deepe
To all, that in the wide deepe wandring arre:
And wast his inward gall with deepe despight,
A virgin widow, whose deepe wounded mind
Then groning deepe, Nor damned Ghost, (quoth he,)
And now it is empassioned so deepe,
Though greeued ghost for vengeance deepe do grone:
Deepe dinted furrowes in the battred mayle;
And helmets hewen deepe, shew marks of eithers might.
To yawning gulfe of deepe Auernus hole.
Deepe, darke, vneasie, dolefull, comfortlesse,
Where in a dongeon deepe huge numbers lay
And cast her colours dyed deepe in graine,
And in a Dongeon deepe him threw without remorse.
Can heart, so plung'd in sea of sorrowes deepe,
So deepe did settle in her gratious thought,
That three yardes deepe a furrow vp did throw:
My dearest Lord, and deepe in dongeon lay,
But all a deepe descent, as darke as hell,
His sad dull eyes deepe sunck in hollow pits,
Deepe written in my heart with yron pen,
For whither he through fatall deepe foresight
Witnesse the dongeon deepe, wherein of late
Does tremble: for his deepe deuouring iawes
With bitter sense of his deepe rooted ill,
And his faint steedes watred in Ocean deepe,
But lay as in a dreame of deepe delight,
That deepe emperst his darksome hollow maw,
But they him layd full low in dungeon deepe,
And after gaue a grone so deepe and low,
And into a deepe sanguine dide the grassie ground.
At last his mightie ghost gan deepe to grone,
Of that was doen, that ruth emperced deepe
And suncke so deepe into their boyling brests,
Night was far spent, and now in Ocean deepe
Dotard (said he) let be thy deepe aduise;
Deepe in his flesh, and opened wide a red floodgate.
His wandring thought in deepe desire does steepe,
Thus in still waues of deepe delight to wade,
And him to ferrie ouer that deepe ford:
Deepe in their flesh, quite through the yron walles,
And deepe him selfe beduked in the same,
That his deepe wounded hart in two did riue,
Where drenched deepe he found in that dull ford
That deepe descended through the hollow ground,
That is the riuer of Cocytus deepe,
That drenched lay full deepe, vnder the Garden side.
Deepe was he drenched to the vpmost chin,
Who groning deepe, thus answerd him againe;
Another wretch, whose carkasse deepe was drent
That word so deepe did in their harts impresse,
And all his senses drowned in deepe senselesse waue.
Cursing his Gods, and himselfe damning deepe:
And cleauing the hard steele, did deepe inuade
That deepe engorgeth all this worldes pray:
Sucking the seas into his entralles deepe,
But nought that falles into this direfull deepe,
Some deepe empurpled as the Hyacint,
And swimming deepe in sensuall desires,
Into the Ocean deepe to driue their weary droue.
Now whenas all the world in silence deepe
To gore her side, yet was the wound not deepe,
By his deepe science, and hell-dreaded might,
In stead thereof sad sighes, and sorrowes deepe
Like an huge Aetn' of deepe engulfed griefe,
Through deepe impression of thy secret might,
In a deepe delue, farre from the vew of day,
From vnder that deepe Rocke most horribly rebounds.
Deepe busied bout worke of wondrous end,
This my deare daughters deepe engraffed ill,
And eke enrooted deepe must be that Tree,
The Damzell was full deepe empassioned,
Her harty words so deepe into the mynd
And the deepe wound more deepe engord her hart,
And the deepe wound more deepe engord her hart,
Thereat she sighed deepe, and after thus complaynd.
Then sighing softly sore, and inly deepe,
Ythrild with deepe disdaine of his proud threat,
Had in his greedie gulfe deuoured deepe,
That so deepe wound through these deare members driue.
Deepe in the bottome of the sea, her bowre
So deepe the deadly feare of that foule swaine
Doth praise thee oft, and oft from Stygian deepe
But labour'd long in that deepe ford with vaine disease.
And after hauing searcht the intuse deepe,
And groning inly deepe, at last his eyes,
In hatefull darkenesse and in deepe horrore,
Deepe indignation and compassion frayle
Downe in a Dongeon deepe he let her fall,
Is not empierst with deepe compassiowne,
Full deepe emplonged was, and drowned nye,
And awfull terror deepe into him strooke,
Ah gentle knight, whose deepe conceiued griefe
Hath in a dungeon deepe her close embard,
And the fraile soule in deepe delight nigh dround:
Entrenched deepe with knife accursed keene,
Albe the wound were nothing deepe imprest,
Seeing his worke now wasted deepe engrieued was.
Downe in the bottome of the deepe Abysse,
Where byting deepe, so deadly it imprest,
But like a wide deepe poke, downe hanging low,
With deepe disdaine, and great indignity,
Of bitter thoughts, which deepe therein infixed lay.
And sighing inly deepe, her thus bespake;
But Scudamour then sighing deepe, thus saide,
Yet inly groning deepe and sighing oft,
Her threw into a dongeon deepe and blind,
Deepe in the bottome of an huge great rocke
Deepe Indus, and Maeander intricate,
Great heapes of Salmons in his deepe bosome:
The thought whereof empierst his hart so deepe,
That is both swift and dangerous deepe withall;
This griefes deepe wound I would to thee disclose,
As women wont, but with deepe sighes, and singulfs few.
Restlesse, recomfortlesse, with heart deepe grieued,
Her heart gan grudge, for very deepe despight
A dreadfull depth, how deepe no man can tell;
Vpon the earth, with hollow eyes deepe pent,
Then vp arose a person of deepe reach,
Seeking to driue away deepe rooted dreede,
But byting deepe therein did sticke so fast,
And more to make the[m] pierce & wound more deepe,
But vertues seat is deepe within the mynd,
Her stubborne hart with inward deepe effect,
That of the deadly swound, in which full deepe
That Calidore it dearly deepe did moue.
His deepe compassion of her dolefull stound,
There she long groueling, and deepe groning lay,
With that he sighed deepe for inward tyne:
Or deepe emboweld in the earth entyre:
Full many a one for me deepe groand and sigh't,
His poysnous point deepe fixed in his hart
But to forray the land, or scoure the deepe.
In so great rage, that them in dongeon deepe
So deepely dinted in the driuen clay,
In his left thigh, and deepely did it thrill:
That her deare hart full deepely made to rew,
He deepely sigh't, and groaned inwardly,
That deeper dint therein it would not make;
She will embosome deeper in your mind,
And tosse the deepes, and teare the firmament,
In deepest Hell, and framd by Furies skill,
When darknesse he in deepest dongeon droue,
And breaking forth, dare tempt the deepest flood,
I will thrust downe into the deepest maine,
With deare compassion deeply did emmoue,
Of sencelesse sleepe did deeply drowned lie,
But knight he now shall neuer more deface:
And can the children of faire light deface.
And that accurst hand-writing doth deface,
That it should not deface all others lesser light?
And with his pride all others powre deface:
First praise of knighthood is, foule outrage to deface.
Maleger doth deface.
And his contrary obiect most deface,
Him his nobilitie so foule deface;
Their groues he feld, their gardins did deface,
Does all their deeds deface, and dims their glories all.
And holy Church with faithlesse hands deface,
That doest all things deface, ne lettest see
Not caring his long labours to deface,
And with lewd termes their louers to deface.
Before misfortune did his hew deface:
From that fowle rudenesse, which did her deface;
And with strong hand their fruitfull rancknes did deface.
And others worth with leasings doest deface,
And titles of nobilitie deface:
With all those shames, that erst ye spake me to deface.
That all your other praises will deface,
champions are defaced.
And knighthood fowle defaced by a faithlesse knight.
And all the hewen stones thereof defaced,
By her strong foe, who had defaced cleene
Them fouly rent, and shamefully defaced had.
And let your fame with falshood be defaced?
And hong their conquered armes for more defame
Then must he her forgoe with foule defame,
Therewith, as thing deuiz'd her to defame.
With forged cause them falsely to defame;
And eke the loue of Ladies foule defame;
And with it beare the burden of defame;
And boastfull Braggadochio to defame,
From all braue knights be banisht with defame:
And many other crimes of foule defame
And wicked customes make, those doe defame
Vnwares into the daunger of defame.
The noblest wights with notable defame:
And foule defame doe decke thy bloudy baner?
Besides the great dishonour and defame,
With his vile tongue, which many had defamed,
The which himselfe, then Ladies more defames,
For neuer more defaming gentle Knight,
Right sowre, & feele the law, the which thou hast defast.
Defast the beautie of the shining sky,
But shall their name for euer be defast,
Altars defyl'd, and holy things defast,
For all his power was vtterly defaste,
To let not others honour be defaste,
That famous moniment hath quite defaste,
Had it defaste; thenceforth reformd her waies,
His speares default to mend with cruell blade;
Which by default I haue not yet defraide.
That he gainst courtesie so fowly did default.
After his foes defeasance did remaine,
Who after Archimagoes fowle defeat,
and Acrasie defeat.
His mighty staffe, that could all charmes defeat:
Shall stoutly him defeat, and thousand Saxons kill.
Foule Errour doth defeate:
Shall him defeate withouten bloud imbrewd:
He Turpine doth defeate, and shame
In which he them defeated euermore,
He them defeated in victorious fight,
But being all defeated, saue a few,
But I them both with equall hap defeated:
Defeated had the other faytour quight,
This mischiefe framd, for their first loues defeature,
Found no defect in his Creatours grace,
Or shame, that euer should so fowle defects
For whose defence he was to shed his blood.
I in defence of mine did likewise stand,
In their defence, nor would for gold or fee
A little backward for his best defence,
That decks and armes your shield with faire defence:
In faire defence and goodly menaging
Vntill that Locrine for his Realmes defence,
For her defence, against that Carle to fight,
He from that deadly throw made no defence,
In better quarrell, then defence of right,
With which the Squire in her defence her sore astound.
And for defence thereof, on th'other end
He is (said he) a man of great defence;
She wore for her defence a mayled habergeon.
Vppon her person for her sure defence,
Doth in defence thereof full stoutly stond:
Whereof she glad, now needing strong defence,
Gainst which the pallid death findes no defence.
Of great defence to ward the deadly feare,
And for thine owne defence on foote alight,
To marchants, but was sau'd with strong defence?
Haue vowd you to defend. Now then your plaint appease.
He hath no powre to hurt, nor to defend;
Defend thine honour, and thy foes confound:
One of his grasping feete, him to defend thereby.
Should need of all his armes, him to defend;
From other couetous feends it to defend,
But euermore him succour, and defend
Beteeme to you this sword, you to defend,
The stroke thereof from entrance may defend;
Ne shield defend the thunder of his throwes:
And those two brethren Giants did defend
With shady Laurell trees, thence to defend
They shall vpreare, and mightily defend
Shall well defend, and Saxons powre suppresse,
Him selfe from deadly daunger to defend:
This hand her wonne, this hand shall her defend.
That from his force seemes nought may it defend;
Him selfe to saue, and daunger to defend,
That can her best defend from villenie;
But euermore my shield did me defend,
Then to defend the feeble in their right,
Guarded of many which did her defend:
But I will it defend, whilst euer that I may.
Defend thee from the vengeance of thy fone,
That O ye heauens defend, and turne away
Her to defend against all forrein foes,
An hideous monster, that doth it defend,
Her to defend, or his to iustifie,
And without sword his person to defend.
So that for want of heires it to defend,
